_exec_summary.SummaryText:
GUADALUPE COOLING COMPANY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN LEVEL III
5-YEAR UPDATE JUNE 2019 

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
 

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

The Guadalupe Cooling Company (GCC) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply to not have accidental releases or emergencies.  The Company endeavors to execute this policy through the daily implementation of its Safety Programs.  Company safety programs include but are not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM).  The PSM Program is an integrated approach to the safe operation of processes using Regulated Substances and forms the Program Level 3 Prevention Program component of the RMP.  The GCC PSM Program is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases, and to deal safely with emergencies if and when they do happen.  It is the primary goal of GCC to protect its employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to Company operations.  With this in mind, the priorities of protection of life, the environment, and then property have been established.   

A Non-responding facility policy has been adopted; however, the Company also recognizes the need to be prepared to respond safely to accidental releases that could occur should established prevention programs fail.  Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated through the local Certified Unified Program Agency (San Luis Obispo County CUPA) and the California Dept of Forestry Fire Department.  Appropriate reports such as the California Hazardous Material Business Plan are filed with these Agencies at required intervals.  Relationships with the local CUPA and Fire Department have been established.  Qualified personnel trained beyond 1910.120(q) Awareness Level would support the Public Responders in the event of an emergency. 

1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

Guadalupe Cooling Company (GCC) is a refrigeration pl

ggestion Box. 

Each of the Programs above may result in recommendations ranging from capital improvements to routine maintenance of the plant. Work Orders are established where necessary. Current planned changes to improve safety are the result of the most recent PHA performed April 16, 2019. A written record of PHA recommendations has been prepared and submitted to GCC management. Completion of the last of the PHA recommendation is expected 3/27/2020. Numerous recommendations had already been implemented, completed or were in the workload as of the submittal of this RMP update. 

End of Executive Summary

ant located 1.7 miles north of Guadalupe, CA.  Frontier Industries constructed the initial facility in the early 1980's, according to the codes and standards locally adopted at that time.  Expansions and upgrades have been made with the assistance of reputable companies, according to the codes and standards in effect in their particular time-frames.  The overall site occupies approximately 20 acres of land.   Several commercial neighbors are located on the same property.  Farmland (row crops) surround the facility.  The Cabrillo Highway (Highway 1) runs along one facility border. 

The facility provides refrigeration effect for the removal of field heat from freshly harvested vegetables, ice-making, and short-term refrigerated storage before the fresh produce is shipped to destination points. 

The Regulated Substance in use is anhydrous ammonia CAS 7664-41-7 (NH3).  Refrigeration equipment consists of Compressors, Pressure Vessels, HydroVac™ Vacuum Tubes, Ice-making equipment, Pressure Cooling Equipment, Cold Storage Room Evaporators plus associated valves, instrumentation, piping and controls.  Vacuum Tubes, Pressure Cooling and Ice-making units are used to pre-cool certain agricultural products; the refrigerated storage portion of the facility is used for short-term product storage.  Evaporators in the storage and dock sections of the facility maintain temperature until product is sold and shipped.  The refrigeration system is configured in a closed-loop system including safety cut-outs, isolation valves and overpressure relief valves installed in key areas.   

GCC owns and may also lease portable refrigeration equipment according to peak seasonal demand, generally from April - November annually.  Depending on geographical & seasonal harvest demand, portable units may also be rented to other companies in other areas from November - April.  Portable equipment consists of Vacuum Tubes, Pressure Coolers and Ice-making equipment.  The portable refrigerat

ion equipment concept has been in use 50+ years and is common to the industry.   

GCC is supported by an affiliate company, Western Precooling Systems (WPS).  WPS is a state-wide and well-known provider of portable ammonia refrigeration equipment and maintenance services.     

1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps 

Accidental Release Prevention Program: 

A comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM) has been established in accordance with CCR 8, 5189.  The PSM Program is specifically intended to promote the safe operation of ammonia-handling equipment and process, and to prevent accidental releases.  GCC strives to make the PSM Program an integral part of daily Plant operation.  Other safety programs are integrated with the PSM Program, to the extent practicable and appropriate. 

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps: 

 - Security patrol and traffic guards have been instituted 
 - Entrance to the facility is closely monitored.  An ID Badge system is in place. 
 - The facility is enclosed with fencing and gates. 
 - Closed Circuit Cameras (CCTV) monitor the facility 24/7/365 
 - Traffic patterns and barriers such as K-rails are established for Process collision prevention 
 - Employees are trained for hazard communication (discovery and communicating) for releases, fires, vandals, etc.  Training is documented.  
 - Only qualified personnel perform work on the process.   
 - Self-closing valves are installed for process oil draining 
 - GCC has established a Food Safety Program that includes sanitation and housekeeping.  There is a staff to maintain the general appearance of the facility on a day-to-day basis, and prevention of combustible materials buildup). 
 - A Lookout system monitors the cold rooms with temperature probes and ammonia sensors.  The Lookout system generates text messages to successive designated phone numbers in the event of an out-of tolerance condition.  If the
